location: 184 St Andrew Street, West Fergus, On
gravity_system: Steel Beams, HSS Columns, Stone Wall
other_materials: Rockwool Insulation, Type 'X' Drywall, Non-Shrink Grout
key_elements: Moment Connections, Shearwalls, Fire-Rated Assemblies, Barrier-Free Washrooms
overall_building_description: The structural design of the Wellington Skin Clinic renovation project integrates advanced engineering techniques to ensure both structural integrity and compliance with modern building codes. The load path analysis reveals a robust system where W8X48 steel beams are employed, providing primary support across spans, with HSS 4x8 columns ensuring vertical load transfer to the foundation. The connection details are meticulously specified, with 3/8" thick steel end plates welded to beams using 1/4" fillet welds, ensuring adequate shear transfer and moment resistance. The beams are anchored into existing stone walls using 3/4" diameter Hilti bolts, spaced at 48 inches on center, with a minimum embedment of 4 inches, providing a secure load path into the stone substrate. The lateral stability is achieved through the use of shear walls, which are reinforced with 1/2" plywood fastened with 2 3/8" nails at 4 inches on center along panel edges and 12 inches in the field, ensuring diaphragm action and lateral load resistance. The shear walls are anchored through the floor with 1/2" epoxy anchors at 24 inches on center, embedded a minimum of 4 inches into the stone wall below, enhancing the overall lateral load path. Fire-rated assemblies are a critical component, with the existing second floor featuring a 1-hour fire rating achieved through the use of 2 layers of 5/8" Type 'X' drywall, providing 40 minutes of fire resistance per layer. The proposed drop ceiling also incorporates a 60-minute fire rating, utilizing similar drywall configurations. Rockwool insulation is specified for sound protection, installed between floor joists and ceiling joists, contributing to both acoustic performance and fire resistance. The ventilation systems are strategically placed within bulkheads below fire separations, ensuring compliance with fire safety regulations. The barrier-free washroom design adheres to stringent accessibility standards, with clear space and transfer space requirements meticulously detailed. Lavatories and water closets are designed to be accessible, with dispensing heights not exceeding 1,200 mm and operable with one hand, ensuring usability for all individuals. The installation of grab bars exceeds minimum code requirements, with L-shaped configurations providing enhanced support for users. The construction details emphasize the importance of proper joint configurations and reinforcement layouts, with non-shrink grout specified above beams to ensure uniform load distribution and prevent settlement. The contractor is instructed to verify the solid bearing condition of the stone wall or to pour a 25MPa concrete cap mix, ensuring a stable foundation for the structural elements. The assembly sequences are carefully planned, with the erection of moment frames and shear walls prioritized to establish the primary structural system before the installation of non-structural elements. The project is certified by a professional engineer, ensuring that all structural components meet the required performance criteria and code compliance standards. This comprehensive approach to structural design and detailing ensures that the Wellington Skin Clinic renovation project achieves both functional and safety objectives, providing a resilient and accessible environment for its occupants.
